This thesis presents new data on the geological development of the South Chinese Yangtze platform concerning the Neoproterozoic III (=NP) to the Early Cambrian. During this time the Yangtze block formed an equatorial fragment along the NW-margin of Gondwana. The evolution of an active continental margin about 1 Ga ago was accompanied by the formation of the continental Jinagnan island-arc along the present southern margin of the Yangtze platform. Provenance investigations carried out clearly point at continental sources. Carbonates and siliciclastics dominate the following four members of the Doushantuo Formation. First post-glacial phosphates and trace element rich black shales occurred independently of facies zones. The geochemical data (e.g. SEE, C, S) indicate no fully marine conditions following the Nantuo glacial. Excessive sulfur concentations, the occurrence of mineralized bacteria and degassing structures may indicate that excess methane released during post-glacial gas hydrate destabilization was oxidized by sulfate reducers. Due to the post-glacial sea level rise early density stratification evolved by influx of seawater across the Jiangnan uplift into the low salinity basin. The occurrence of sedimentation gaps at the Jiangnan region confirms the protected character of the basin during the NP III. Repeatedly transgressive events have left organic- and trace element rich deposits on the platform yielding remarkable negative delta13C-excursions. Two negative NP isotope shifts have not yet been clearly reported from South China, although they are known from other regions. Mass layers of the nitrate reducing bacteria Vendotaenia observed within the transgressive units reflecting the expansion of dysoxic conditions onto the platform. The distribution of SEE is comparable with the results of the modern Black Sea, indicating extensive stagnant conditions within the ancient water column. In particular the global character of the carbon isotope excursions outlines a relationship with sea level changes of lower order. Following this scenario the geochemical results may be consistently explained by intermittently upwelling of trace element enriched stagnant deep waters with light carbon isotope ratios. Evaporites and karst features occurring within the upper Dengying Formation verify a drastic warming of the atmosphere at the end of the NP. The development of hypersaline conditions on the platform enhanced the density stratification significantly. In this context sulfate minium zones may have evolved along the density boundaries within the water column. Sulfur isotope data from the deep water facies show values close to the coexisting seawater sulfate and do support this hypothesis. The dawn of the Cambrian is characterized by dramatic changes within the sedimentary record. Primary phosphates were deposited along the formerly exposed and karstified platform margin. The occurrence of hardgrounds, condensation, reworking, basal breccias, unusual element enrichments and the ‚Äúmixing‚Ä? of fossil zones at the platform attests a substantial transgressive event. Especially during the Nemakit-Daldynian the carbon isotope record shows exceptional short time fluctuations. The accompanying tectono-magmatic activity is preserved by metabentonites and pyroclastics within the sediments. As a result the reactivation of a former fault system along the platform margin occurred and may have contributed to the formation of a stratiform Ni-Mo-ore layer. This work provides some sedimentological evidence towards a participation of basinal brines in the ore forming process. On the other hand the dramatically decreased sedimentation rates during the early Cambrian transgression accompanied by episodically upwelling of stagnant waters may have crucially contributed to the formation of the ore. The mass occurrence of metazoans in the direct vicinity of the ore may indicate a nutrient-coupling for example by chemotrophic bacteria. The initiation of subsidence within the Jiangnan region is preserved by the deposition of thick black shales. Towards the end of the transgression light delta34S-values within the deep water sediments testify a break-up of the established sulfate minimum zones. In contrast to the NP the Nemakit-Daldynian values of DeltaTOC decrease and signal a significant change within the global carbon cycle. These changes can be roughly correlated with the first occurrence of large coprolites at the Tommotian/Atdabanian boundary and may reflect a successive metabolic rearrangement of early metazoans towards photoautotrophic based food chains.
